content: It is hard to imagine topics more interesting than the structure and evolution of the planet, as manifested by phenomena as dramatic as earthquakes. The goal of this course is to introduce students about these phenomena via an introduction to seismology, which is one of the cornerstones on the modern earth sciences. Seismology has been defined as the study of earthquakes and associated phenomena, or thestudy of elastic waves propagating in the earth. By integrating techniques and data from physics, mathematics, and geology, seismology has produced a remarkably sharp picture of the earth?¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s interior. The subject has much to offer mineralogists or petrologists studying the composition of the earth?¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s interior, students of tectonics interested in processes of the lithosphere, geologists interested in the nature and evolution of the crust, engineers concerned with seismic hazards, and planetologists interested in the evolution of terrestrial planets.On completion of the course the student should be able to explain general concepts of earthquake seismology, and its link to society. They may be able to explain source, path and receiver as the main components in seismology. They will be able to demonstrate how the earthquake mechanism is derived from waveform data. They can discuss the basics of the seismic attenuation and how the observation of earthquakes leads to improved Earth models.
